title: Learn ISO
description: ISO controls the sensitivity to light...

content.content: ISO refers to your camera sensor's sensitivity to light.
Think of ISO like sunglasses - the higher the ISO, the more "light-sensitive" your sensor becomes.

2.title: When to Use High vs. Low ISO

content.content: Use low ISO (e.g. 100–200) on sunny days to get sharp, clean photos.
Use high ISO (e.g. 1600–3200) in low light (night scenes, concerts), but expect more grain (noise).
The higher the ISO, the more digital noise appears in your photo — visible grain, less detail, and color accuracy.
Boosting ISO can help you use faster shutter speeds in low light — useful for freezing motion without blur.
Shutter speed refers to how long the camera's shutter is open when taking a photo.
Slow (1/10s or slower) → Blur motion (waterfalls, night lights)
Slower shutter speed allows more light, good for dark settings, but risks blur without a tripod.
Light painting, star trails, or smooth water all use slow shutter speeds.
Panning can create a sharp subject with a blurred background.
Aperture contorols the size of the opening in the lens.
Think of aperture like the eye - the wider the aperture, the wider the opening in the lens.
Wide aperture (f/1.8) → Shallow depth of field → Blurry background (great for portraits)
Narrow aperture (f/11+) → Deep focus → More in focus (great for landscapes)
A wider aperture lets in more light, helping in low-light situations without needing a flash or high ISO.
Wider aperture = more light and blur
Narrow aperture = sharper background but needs more light or slower shutter speed.
